In The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church), temple work refers to the religious ceremonies and ordinances that are performed in temples. These ceremonies and ordinances are considered sacred and are considered essential for the salvation and exaltation of believers.

Temple work includes a variety of ordinances, such as baptism for the dead, the endowment, and sealing ceremonies

In The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church), temple work refers to the religious ceremonies and ordinances that are performed in temples. These ceremonies and ordinances are considered sacred and are considered essential for the salvation and exaltation of believers.

Temple work includes a variety of ordinances, such as baptism for the dead, the endowment, and sealing ceremonies. These ordinances are performed on behalf of individuals who are deceased and are believed to be essential for the salvation of those individuals in the afterlife.

Temple work also includes other ceremonies and ordinances that are performed for living individuals, such as sealings (marriages and other covenant-making ceremonies that are believed to extend beyond this life).

Temple work is an important part of the worship and beliefs of members of the LDS Church. It is believed that through temple work, believers can participate in important religious covenants and gain a closer connection with God. Temple...

In the Book of Mormon studied by members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, both Lehi and his son Nephi have a vision of the tree of life. The vision is recorded in 1 Nephi chapter 8, and Nephi records the interpretation starting in chapter 11. I highly recommend you read these excellent chapters!

The tree of life and its amazing fruit are likened to the love of God. The rod of iron that people hold and follow to the tree is the word of God. By holding fast to the word of God, we are led to the tree and the love of God.

The temple endowment is a blessing of knowledge and covenants that we make as individuals. It builds on and enhances the covenants we make when we are baptized. These covenants of keeping the commandments, sacrificing to build up the kingdom of God on the earth, and serving to help and lift others can help keep us holding fast to the iron rod, or the word of God, and help move us forward on the path to reaching the full love of God.

Why is the need for secrecy surrounding Latter-day Saint temples?

Did the Savior tell everybody everything he taught? There were things he specifically taught the Twelve Apostles that he did not teach to all of the rest of his followers. Why? because they would not be able to receive it.

This is what Christ taught his followers:

“Give not that which is holy unto the dogs, neither cast ye your pearls before swine, lest they trample them under their feet, and turn again and rend you.” Matthew 7:6

On one occasion when Christ was teaching his followers this happened:

“And he said, Therefore said I unto you, that no man can come unto me, except it were given unto him of my Father.

From that time many of his disciples went back, and walked no more with him.

Then said Jesus unto the twelve, Will ye also go away?” John 6:65–7

It is not that things are secret. It is that they are sacred so are not shared with someone unless they meet the criteria that the Lord has established. The Temple Endowment was given through the Spirit and can only be understood through the Spirit and Heavenly Father will reveal things to you through the Spirit.

There are those who are not members of the Church who seem to know as much about the Temple at least what goes on in the Temple as well as I do. However, to them it is not sacred and they seek to mock or make light of the things of God. That is why we seek give that which is Holy to the dogs nor cast pearls before swine.

As others have said It is easy enough to find out what goes on in the temple using search engines, however, you will never understand the endowment without the Spirit.

God does not allow any random worship in His house, because everything must be for the glory of the Father. And about the glory of the Father we read :

For behold, this is my work and my glory—to bring to pass the immortality and eternal life of man.
—Moses 1:39

And about work, Jesus said :

Verily, verily, I say unto you, He that believeth on me, the works that I do shall he do also; and greater works than these shall he do; because I go unto my Father.
—John 14:12

Therefore, what was Jesus’ work? To save all mankind from death through vicarious work, even through Christ’s atonement.

And what is this “greater works” that we accomplish, then? To vicariously baptize the dead in preparation for their salvation, even through baptism for the dead. (See 1 Corinthians 15:29)

As Jesus Christ did show the way, even giving us a perfect example, including getting baptized by immersion from someone with the proper authority, and then serving others, then knowing death and being resurrected, then ascending to the Father, so shall it be for everyone who believe in Him. As Jesus Christ kept all the commandments, even unto righteousness, so must we.

Those who claim to follow Christ, but do not abide by these things, are like robbers who seek to enter in the Kingdom of Heaven through the back door (John 10:1).

Everything that happen inside temples are for the glory of the Father, that is to help the children of God return to the Father, even by allowing them to accept baptism even if they are dead (1 Peter 3:21).

The temple is a very important part of Latter-day Saint worship. Why is it so important, and what goes on inside the temple?

Original question: The temple is a very important part of Latter-day Saint worship. Why is it so important, and what goes on inside the temple?

The temple is the place God has authorized the performance of the exalting ordinances of endowment and sealing. It is also the only place where we are authorized to perform the saving ordinances of baptism and confirmation in behalf of our deceased ancestors, who never had the opportunity during their lifetime.

Original question: The temple is a very important part of Latter-day Saint worship. Why is it so important, and what goes on inside the temple?

The temple is the place God has authorized the performance of the exalting ordinances of endowment and sealing. It is also the only place where we are authorized to perform the saving ordinances of baptism and confirmation in behalf of our deceased ancestors, who never had the opportunity during their lifetime.

Over the door you well see engraved HOLINESS TO THE LORD, just a Solomon had his temple. The latter-day temple is no less a sacred place. We sacrifice to build them, maintain them, and worship in them. Some of us have to make drastic lifestyle changes just to be able to qualify to enter. Once inside the temple, we are all equal before God, dressed in white, making covenants to follow the teachings of Jesus Christ and thinking about preparing to enter God’s presence.

Regardless of our state of preparation for the temple, we attend our weekly services in the meetinghouse near wear we live. Attending our meetings is part of our preparation to go to the temple. You are welcome to attend with us any Sunday you like.

Ooh, ooh! I’ve got this.

Behold, my ultimate weapon in conversion. Behold and weep, ye disconsolate!

Okay, I used the Duncan Hines recipe, but it was very similar.

Had enough? Ready to convert? No? Fine. Have a sample of this:

Family size. The horrors!

You stand no chance. Surely, you’re already salivating at the opportunity to talk with me and my companion about the sweet, sweet gospel of Christ and feeling the delicious promptings of the Holy Ghost around your esophageal area telling you that you know this is true, right? And we can schedule a baptism next week and I’ll bring more?

I jest, of course, but only half-jesting. You see, even though here on Quora, I’ve taken a solemn no-proselyting vow, after this post I shall surely have to repent!

The reality is that, as both a full-time missionary, part time ward mission leader, and all-the-time member, I haven’t really done anything. I’ve been around to teach the gospel when people were willing to hear it. I exemplified Christ by doing service, and sometimes that service was baking yummy treats.

Her name was not Sarah. She was a lovely middle-aged woman living in the Hampton Roads area of Virginia. One night, my companion and I stopped to put fuel in our car and I noticed her putting fuel in hers in the island next to ours and she was sobbing.

“Excuse me, but can I help you?” I offered, pulling out a handkerchief and offering it to her.

“Oh!” She burst, “I’m sorry, I really am. It’s nothing, really.” She took the handkerchief and wiped away tears.

My companion, worried that we wouldn’t be home in time for curfew, motioned to the car and I deftly waved him off.

“I’m Elder Dillon, and this is my companion Elder Bousfield, and we’re missionaries for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. We’re here to help however we can.”

“Oh, aren’t you sweet!” Sarah said, “I’m just a mess because my ex just died.”

“I’m sorry to hear that.”

“I loved him so. You wouldn’t think it being my ex, but he really was my best friend.”

“I lost my mom when I was a child. I know exactly how that feels.”

“I haven’t been to church in ages. But the pastor said that he was going to Hell and now I’ll be…is it true?”

“Sarah,” I offered, “we’ve got to get home now, but I don’t believe you or your ex are consigned to Hell.”

“Do you think I’ll see him again?” She sobbed again and I told her to just keep the handkerchief.

“I do. Same as I’ll see my mother. Listen, why don’t you call us at this number,” I handed her our business card, “and we can stop by and discuss this with you. And, if it’ll help, I’ll bring blueberry muffins.”

She smiled through her tears. “God bless you, Elder, and you, Elder,” she said, as we waved and sped off into the night.

The next day, we were surprised to get a call—it doesn’t usually happen. “This is Sarah. We talked last night?”

“Of course! Are you feeling better?”

“I am, thanks to you. You told me to call and you’d come over.”

“Well, yes. I think we have some time this morning. I just need to bake some muffins. How does 10:00 sound?”

“Sounds great.” She told us her address and I started baking.

We showed up at her house promptly at 10:00 with steaming, fresh muffins, and, as she was single and we couldn’t go in (mission rules), we ate them on the porch and shared our understanding of the afterlife. She told us how her church pastor was always preaching hellfire and damnation and how it didn’t feel right to her so she stopped going and we invited her to come to our church and see if it felt different. She thought we were awesome people—can’t disagree there—but it still took a couple of weeks of invitations to get her to attend services and meet others from the branch. We taught her the basics of the gospel and as she came to realize that Hell was not the final resting place of either her beloved ex or herself, she had a great burden lifted off her shoulders. We helped her quit smoking so she could get baptized, and she asked me to baptize her.

I stayed there for a few more months and helped her along, but the branch had great members who welcomed her in and when I left, it was time for more tears, but we both knew she was in good hands.

Now, I pick up a few lessons here:

  1. We’re not shallow. I really was concerned for her that night at the gas station. I wasn’t looking for a convert. I was looking to help someone crying.
  2. We’re honest and not pushy.
  3. We listen and adapt our teaching to what people need to hear. Back in those days, we had a progressive series of discussions that laid out the gospel logically. Thankfully, we listened to the Spirit and tossed those out when we taught Sarah. She needed some meat before milk. Nowadays, I understand, missionaries are trained to be this flexible in their teaching.
  4. Our love for Sarah shone through, not just in muffins, but in everything we did. There was never a question in her mind that we were there for her and would do anything in our power to do, and not because she was a number, but because we genuinely cared.
  5. We introduced her to the local members, so that she had new friends who could be there for her when we moved on.
  6. She did relapse on the smoking. We helped her quit again. As many smokers can tell you, sometimes, it takes several tries. We were patient, loving, and kind.

In truth, though, we didn’t convert her. She was already converted when I saw her. Note how she told us that “it didn’t feel right” in her former church? Well, it felt right to her when we taught her, and when she went to the local branch services. There are some people who are just so prepared that all you have to do is fill the font and she was one of them. She had heard how the Mormons were evil and loved telling her friends on the phone, “Oh, my little Mormon devils are here. Yes, the missionaries. Well, you should come over and listen to them!”

I have no doubt we’ll see each other again.

Ronald Kimmons
Former Missionary in Taiwan at The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (Mormons) (2004–2006) · Author has 14.4K answers and 27.4M answer views · 3y ·

Can an endowed Latter-day Saint get a limited-use temple recommend? If he did something making him unworthy to enter the temple could the bishop, as the member is on the repentance process, determine him to be ready to do baptisms but not endowments?

Nope.

Limited use is only for the youth that are not of age, so they can do baptisms for the dead, etc.

If one is unworthy, they don't get a recommend or the one they had is retracted. Only after completing the repentance process and are considered worthy will they get any kind of recommend.

Do latter day saints believe in monolatry?

We are running into the problem of language highlighted by Wittgenstein—he called it sprachspiel or “language games”. A word only has meaning as the result of the “rule” of the “game” being played.

The term monolatry was, from what I gather, first used by W.R. Smith and later by Julius Wellhausen both scholars of religion attempting to reconcile the Old Testament worship of God with ideas expressed, for example, in Psalms 82:6 “I have said, Ye are gods; and all of you are children of the most High.”

When very precise terminology is employed, it is often purposed to create a distinction or defini

We are running into the problem of language highlighted by Wittgenstein—he called it sprachspiel or “language games”. A word only has meaning as the result of the “rule” of the “game” being played.

The term monolatry was, from what I gather, first used by W.R. Smith and later by Julius Wellhausen both scholars of religion attempting to reconcile the Old Testament worship of God with ideas expressed, for example, in Psalms 82:6 “I have said, Ye are gods; and all of you are children of the most High.”

When very precise terminology is employed, it is often purposed to create a distinction or definition of something that is not entirely understood. As understanding increases, so too does the precision of the definition.

I would point to the atom as evidence of this linguistic evolution. We understand atoms to be very different than did the greeks who created the word, yet the basic definition of the word remains accurate and meaningful even though the understanding behind it has since deepened.

I believe in fathers, but I also believe that I have only one father. Genetically, I suppose they could tinker with the chromosomes and splice in genetic materials—meaning, you could manufacture an exception to my example, but generally it is accepted that a person has but ONE father although many men are fathers.

There is but one capital “G” God to us. He is our Father—we are His offspring. That makes us gods as well. We worship our Father in the name of Jesus Christ:

29 And we know that all men must repent and believe on the name of Jesus Christ, and worship the Father in his name, and endure in faith on his name to the end, or they cannot be saved in the kingdom of God. Doctrine and Covenants 20

We are taught that God is eternal and unchanging. Time is measured only unto men. See, Alma 40

I don’t speak for The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, so what I say here is only my private understanding.

No.

We worship our Father through the Lord Jesus Christ, who is our advocate with the Father. We pray to and worship the Father in the name of Jesus Christ. Jesus is our brother, the firstborn of God, and the only being capable of paying a price we do not have the capability at present to understand.

Having successfully paid that price, Jesus Christ became equal with the Father, his Father and our Father. Jesus is now able to grant us entry and return to the place where God the Father dwells—but Jesus cannot be arbitrary, capricious or unfair in any way—perfection denies that. Therefore, Jesus can save only those who truly accept His gift and seek His forgiveness.

We also believe that it takes a male and a female to create life. That gender is an essential element of human pre-mortal, mortal and post-mortal identity, power and purpose. (Yes, I get that there are examples of parthenogenesis in other forms of life—and, yes, we don’t understand the why of everything.)

Therefore, we have Heavenly Parents not just a Heavenly Father.

There is so much we don’t know yet and this lack of precise understanding gives rise to so many of the differences between various religious denominations. To be one, for example, is legitimately interpreted in more ways that I can count.

Just as children are given information about the world as soon as they have developed the ability to understand the information, we are given information personally, as private revelatory experience, and in the form of scripture and teachings to the world from those given special authority to reveal and teach doctrines.

I am struggling to learn as much as I can, but from what little I have gleaned thus far, the term monolatry as used and defined in the references I have studied does not fit the beliefs of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

For now, I’m going to focus my efforts on coming unto Christ as He has commanded. Along the way, I hope to gather as much understanding as possible in this fallen and dark world where we came, voluntarily, to learn how to choose good over evil.

Do some Latter-day Saints wear temple garments?

All members of our church who have made covenants in any one of our temples wear the temple garment as a protection and a reminder or those covenants. If any member has taken the garment off and does not wear it any more, they have made a choice to do so.

What is the cultural significance of the temple in Latter-day Saint worship?

Members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints go to the Temple to make certain Covenants with the Lord and receive our Endowment. Think of it like this, we make promises and we receive promises in return. It is in the Temple that members are given or authorized to wear the Garments or “special underwear” as part of the covenants they make. This is called initiatory ordinances. After a person receives their Endowment they can be married or sealed to their family in the Temple.

After a member has gone to the Temple for themselves they then can go through the Temple for the dead. An Endowment session lasts about 90 minutes. Baptisms, initiatory ordinances, and Endowment sessions are performed for our dead ancestors. Sealings can then be performed to seal families together for time and all eternity. This is taught to members and their children from the youngest to the oldest this is essential in the teachings of the Church.

It is important to note these ordinances although recorded and documented DO NOT make the dead members of the Church or are binding in any way. What this means is if the Church has done work for your ancestors and for some reason you feel this forces them to be a member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints even in our eyes that is not the case. The Church believes this only allows them to accept or reject these ordinances if THEY choose as these are earthly ordinances with eternal consequences.

I would also note that Temples are closed on Sundays and are open Monday through Saturday for these sessions.

Why is attending the temple an important part of Mormon worship?

Original question: Why is attending the temple an important part of Mormon worship?

Members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints believe that important ordinances can only be performed in the temple, such as proxy baptisms for ancestors who did not have the opportunity to be baptized and eternal marriages. Members also make important covenants with God in the temple, such as a covenant to be chaste and to obediently sacrifice and consecrate your time, talents, and everything you possess to build up the Kingdom of God on the earth.

In the temple, Church members receive these ordinances and covenants, along with other lectures, knowledge, and blessings, in preparation for the life to come in the Celestial Kingdom of God.

In other words, the temple helps and teaches us to live a more holy life in preparation for eternal life with Jesus.

Is the Latter Day Saint religion (Mormons) monotheistic?

In the common view of the term, yes. We worship one God, and don’t believe in any divinity not associated with Him.

But if you use the technical definitions, Latter-day Saint theology would perhaps be more accurately henotheistic. Leaving aside the question as to whether believing Jesus Christ does not share essence with the Father (as in the common Trinity doctrine) makes Latter-day Saint theology non-monotheistic (it’s debatable), there are other doctrines that make strict monotheism questionable.

For example, it is doctrine that as children of God, we humans are children not just of a Heavenl

In the common view of the term, yes. We worship one God, and don’t believe in any divinity not associated with Him.

But if you use the technical definitions, Latter-day Saint theology would perhaps be more accurately henotheistic. Leaving aside the question as to whether believing Jesus Christ does not share essence with the Father (as in the common Trinity doctrine) makes Latter-day Saint theology non-monotheistic (it’s debatable), there are other doctrines that make strict monotheism questionable.

For example, it is doctrine that as children of God, we humans are children not just of a Heavenly Father, but also of a Heavenly Mother. While some of the same issues arise as with the Father-Son-Holy Ghost godhead in wondering whether that even qualifies as “multiple gods,” given that marriage even in life is taught to be intended as a sort of oneness, doctrine would still have her being a distinct individual.

Furthermore, like the Eastern Christian Churches the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints believes in theosis. That is to say, the doctrine teaches that Biblical references to becoming like God, or heirs of God, are being literal: humans who follow the gospel of Jesus Christ will become beings like unto God, and could perhaps be called gods at that point. Surely, if that occurs, then a strict definition of “monotheism” could not apply.

Nevertheless, “polytheism” would be utterly inappropriate. Despite the above exceptions to the monotheistic definition, there is no provision whatsoever for worship of other beings, particularly separate from worship of the Father.

The appropriate term for believing in the possibility of multiple gods, but only worshiping one, as I mentioned above, is henotheism. It’s…still not perfect, as there are some implications of henotheism too that don’t really apply. But it’s technically closer than other terms that seem to be candidates.

Nevertheless, the distinctions are somewhat academic (none of the exceptions are themselves separate from the single, supreme God the Father), so common parlance would just group us in with the monotheistic religions, because there’s not really a practical difference. Many people, even having all this explained to them, would just roll their eyes at the sophistry and call us monotheists.

How do Latter-day Saints worship?

I apologize for taking so long. I’d meant to answer yesterday, but got distracted by Usain Bolt. That man is a marvel!

Worship takes many forms and I’ll attempt to address the three most familiar to Latter-Day Saints: personal worship, congregational worship, and temple worship.

Personal Worship

Everyone’s different, but from what I’ve been taught and try to follow myself, we’re looking at prayer in the morning and evening, at meals, and throughout the day as needed. “Pray always” is a common saying in the scriptures, and this is explained to be “carry a prayer in your heart” and “perform all you

I apologize for taking so long. I’d meant to answer yesterday, but got distracted by Usain Bolt. That man is a marvel!

Worship takes many forms and I’ll attempt to address the three most familiar to Latter-Day Saints: personal worship, congregational worship, and temple worship.

Personal Worship

Everyone’s different, but from what I’ve been taught and try to follow myself, we’re looking at prayer in the morning and evening, at meals, and throughout the day as needed. “Pray always” is a common saying in the scriptures, and this is explained to be “carry a prayer in your heart” and “perform all you labors in the name of the Lord.” If a Saint is doing this, every day is a worshipful experience.

Scripture study is recommended to be a daily experience as well. It might be just a verse it might be a chapter or more. Some people study for X minutes, some for X pages…there’s no “expected” or set guidance. The point is, open the scriptures and prayerfully read them and you’ll receive inspiration for your needs.

Fasting is encouraged on a monthly basis: the first Sunday worship service of most months is “Fast and Testimony meeting” which is often shorthanded to “Fast Sunday” as in the sentence, “Tomorrow is Fast Sunday,” often accompanied by groans from the kids (and silent “I hear you” from the parents), though, as Isaiah writes, we really should look at it from a more positive place—we are humans, after all, and not perfect.

Weekly Worship

Speaking of Sundays, that’s the day for most weekly Sabbath worship services (I say most because the church, as a worldwide entity, remains flexible to local congregational needs, but we try to do it on Sunday.) We meet in “wards” which are typically geographically distributed, and contain some few hundreds of people.

Our worship services are typically in three roughly-hour-long meetings: Sacrament, Sunday School, and Quorum.

Sacrament meeting is very much like any other Christian worship service, I’m led to believe. There’s a hymn, invocation, announcements and business, then a hymn and passing of the sacrament (aka communion, Eucharist), and following that, a few talks from members of the congregation who are usually assigned a topic such as “Faith” or “Family History” or “Christ” a week or so in advance (this may be different from other faiths, where a preacher would handle the talking for this period instead). Following the talks is a hymn and benediction. The meeting usually lasts around 70 minutes.

Sunday School is about a 40-minute-long classroom setting where adults learn doctrine together while youth get age-specific education about doctrine

Quorum meeting is more of the same, except that we separate by sex into male and female quorums or groups, and discuss doctrinal application specific to our lives (the distinction here is that women teach women, men teach men in these quorum meetings as the church recognizes that different roles in life necessitate different applications of the same teachings—and they are, generally, the same teachings). In all cases, the classroom settings are open-question, discussion-encouraged affairs, with the instructor (of which I’ve been one for some 20 years now) presenting a prescribed question or topic to the class and helps to direct the discussion.

Following services, the rest of the day is open to do as the family desires, though many leaders have suggested keeping the rest of the day’s activities in the same worshipful spirit of the Sabbath. Many take this as an invitation to do additional scripture reading and prayer, or spend time exclusively with family…it’s completely up to the individual there, really.

Temple Worship

Unlike most other Christian denominations, Saints also have temples: special buildings specifically used for performing sacred ceremonies for ourselves and the deceased. These ordinances include baptism for the dead, washing and anointings, endowment (which is a series of covenants and instruction that helps us better understand the plan of salvation and our role in it) and sealings to one another for time and eternity. These are sacred—not secret—ceremonies that we want everyone to receive and participate in, but due to the holy nature of both the temple and the ceremonies, we require participants to be worthy, as determined in a temple recommend worthiness interview. Because of the sacredness of the work, we are asked not to discuss the particulars of these ceremonies outside of the temple as those who are unprepared will not understand (and frequently misunderstand) their significance.

Saints are encouraged to attend the temple as often as feasible. By my calculations, for every temple-worthy Saint alive today, there are 1,000 people who have not been so blessed, and thus there is a lot of vicarious work to be done; literally, a lifetime of service to the human family.

Summary

While I’ve shared my own thoughts and words here, you’ll find it jives with what’s written at The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints or Mormon.org | What is the Mormon Church and Religion? It’s important to point out that not every Saint is, well, Saintly—some are new converts just getting their bearings and fired up with the Spirit of rebirth, while others are slogging along, “enduring to the end” in the faith of their father’s father’s fathers, and no one Saint can be pointed to as an example of all believers, but hopefully we comport ourselves worthy of being called Christian, in word and demeanor.

Is freedom of religion disrespectful of religion? If a country allows its citizens to choose a religion or no religion at all, what does that say about what the government thinks of religion as objective reality?
Originally Answered: Is freedom of religion disrespectful of religion?

Every entity or collective determines what it considers disrespectful. Some religions encourage reflection while others consider any dissent as heresy. You can't tell someone how they are supposed to feel.

Its like wearing a Confederate T-shirt: someone may not intend to mean it as an offensive symbol, but they can't dictate that observers accept it as non-offensive. You may not intend on being offensive to some religion, but its not for you to decide. If you really don't want to offend, you have to accept their terms.

This is why I don't bother worrying about offending religious people over their religion. Somehow, it became social taboo to be disrespectful of someones beliefs. But that gives a blank check to the religious person to determine what is acceptable and what not. Ok, someone thinks homosexuality is sinful, but why should that dictate civil law? Or someone else thinks its blasphemous to create an image of their prophet. The bottom line is in order not to offend some religions, you have to more or less adopt their rules and customs to be inoffensive. So its not worth the effort to try to comply. I'm not going to try to argue some religious person should not be offended by something I say or do, I just don't care.

What is the structure of a Latter Day Saint temple?

Original question: What is the structure of a Latter Day Saint temple?

The 1836 Kirtland Temple was brick masonry with a plaster coating. The 1845 Nauvoo Temple was limestone blocks.

After the Latter-day Saints were forced out of the United States at gunpoint and the temple was destroyed, the pioneer-era temples of the Rocky Mountains were built of sandstone, starting with the 1877 St. George Utah Temple. In the case of the 1893 Salt Lake Temple, it was solid granite. Church President Brigham Young (1801–1877), who never did anything small, told architect Truman O. Angell (1810–1887) he wanted i

Original question: What is the structure of a Latter Day Saint temple?

The 1836 Kirtland Temple was brick masonry with a plaster coating. The 1845 Nauvoo Temple was limestone blocks.

After the Latter-day Saints were forced out of the United States at gunpoint and the temple was destroyed, the pioneer-era temples of the Rocky Mountains were built of sandstone, starting with the 1877 St. George Utah Temple. In the case of the 1893 Salt Lake Temple, it was solid granite. Church President Brigham Young (1801–1877), who never did anything small, told architect Truman O. Angell (1810–1887) he wanted it to last until the end of the Millennium.

The Salt Lake Temple is currently under a five-year renovation and seismic retrofitting. Today, temples are designed mostly with steel framing.

The Helena Montana Temple under construction

In case you were not asking about building materials or methods, I can tell you about the temple’s organizational structure. Each temple has a president, who is an experienced Church leader, a high priest, who holds the keys to all the ordinances performed inside. At his side is the matron, invariably his wife, who is also an experienced Church leader.

The president and matron of the Atlanta Georgia Temple

Each of them has two counselors or assistants. At least two of them must be present in the temple at all times it is open. For three couples covering a five-day schedule, that can be nearly a full-time assignment. The temple president is also assisted by a recorder and an engineer, which, unusually, can be paid positions. There are assistant recorders and clerical staff, gardeners, laundry staff, and, in the temple where I serve, a crew of nine janitorial employees who work all night long. They are the only janitors of which I know who get dressed up to go to work.

The president and matron of the Accra Ghana Temple

But most of the people working in the temple (the staff, so to speak) are ordinance workers, men and women in approximate equal numbers, who perform the priestly functions that can only be performed in the temple. They are regular Church members who have been called to serve in the temple usually one day a week. They work in shifts with shift coordinators who manage the schedules and staffing of all areas in the temple. An assistant shift coordinator is usually charged with training workers. Ordinance workers tend to be of retirement age, but don’t have to be.

The president and matron of the Tokyo Japan Temple

Most temples are open from Tuesday through Saturday, and temple patrons, the Church members who come to participate, usually come by appointment. The come in groups, as couples, and alone.

Latter-day Saints going to serve in the St. George Utah Temple

In case you were not asking about the temple, but rather the local congregation, then you should know that Latter-day Saint temples don’t have a congregation that meets there weekly, there are no Sunday services, and that it is a different kind of worship than what we do in our local meetinghouse. If you go to the temple on a Sunday, you will find the parking lot empty and the the door locked.

The local organization of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints has stakes, wards, led by stake presidents and bishops, respectively. There is stake council and a ward council. Wards meet weekly and stakes meet approximately twice a year. Men participate in priesthood quorums and women in the Relief Society. At Sunday meetings, you will often hear leaders encouraging members to attend the temple as often as their circumstances permit. You are welcome to come of any of our meetinghouses on any Sunday.

How do Latter-day Saints determine whether someone is worthy to enter the temple?

Latter-day Saints meet with their bishop (congregational leader) or one of his two counselors and then with the stake president (leader of a group of congregations) or one of his two counselors. Each of these men asks interview questions listed in the link below. The member should be able to answer them all in a way that demonstrates his faithfulness. If not, then a temple recommend would be withheld until he’s able to solve whatever problems exist with the help of church leaders.

What are the core beliefs of Mormonism?

The Articles of Faith are a good summary, written by Joseph Smith.

Another good source, in encyclopedic format, is True to the Faith.

I would boil everything down to three points:

  1. God exists, and we are literally His children. Our spirits are the offspring of God. As that implies, we can become like God if we do what God says. Indeed, that is God’s entire purpose: no lesser purpose would make any sense. Why would God settle for anything less?

The Articles of Faith are a good summary, written by Joseph Smith.

Another good source, in encyclopedic format, is True to the Faith.

I would boil everything down to three points:

  1. God exists, and we are literally His children. Our spirits are the offspring of God. As that implies, we can become like God if we do what God says. Indeed, that is God’s entire purpose: no lesser purpose would make any sense. Why would God settle for anything less?
  2. Jesus Christ is our savior and our only path to salvation. However, this does not mean that those who do not accept Christ will be condemned to fire and pitchforks for eternity. It just means that they will not reach their full potential.
  3. Ongoing prophecy and revelation are vital to biblical religion. One cannot claim to believe in the Bible and then say that the time of prophets is over. This actually contradicts the Bible. Joseph Smith was a modern prophet who restored the Church of Jesus Christ to the world after it had been lost.

What is the name of the Eternal Father worshipped by Latter Day Saints?

First, point to note that I suppose this question to mean “Eternal Father” as Heavenly Father, the one Jesus Christ addressed in His prayers, the same who testifies of the Son in Matthew 3:17 and Matthew 17:5, and not the title “Everlasting Father” found in Isaiah identifying our Lord and Savior, Jesus Christ.

Generally speaking, the name of our Father in Heaven has not been revealed to mankind at this time because the only name that matters is Jesus Christ for now. Perhaps some prophets have learned that sacred name from time to time, but they never taught it, neither recorded it in the Scriptures. (For example, the Hebrews and the Jews always substituted the name of God by something else.)

However, Latter-day Saints identify Heavenly Father by Elohim, which is the most sacred name found in the Hebrew texts; there is no name greater than this, and we consider the Father to be greater than the Son (see John 14:28).

In short, Latter-day Saints do not address Heavenly Father by that name, but simply call Him “Father”, as Jesus instructed in the Lord’s Prayer (Matthew 6) in response to the disciples asking how they should address God.

Why are temples so important to Latter-day Saints?

Original question: Why are temples so important to Latter-day Saints?

With the understanding that a temple is not an ordinary meetinghouse, but rather the house of God reserved for sacred purposes, the temple is as important as life itself. Only in the temple can we receive the blessings that allow us, should we remain faithful, to eventually walk with our families into the presence of God.

So it’s not just some big fancy church. It represents the culmination of the teachings of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

What is meant by "sealing" in Latter-day Saint temples?

Original question: What is meant by "sealing" in Latter-day Saint temples?

A sealing is a promise from God that your relationship, whether marital or parent-child, will last beyond death as long as you remain faithful. It is a sacred covenant for those who have spiritually prepared themselves.

If a temple is unavailable, how do Latter-day Saints worship?

Temples are not regular places of Sunday worship for members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. They are quite different from the thousands of regular chapels or meetinghouses all over the world that are used for Sunday services. All are welcome, regardless of membership.

There are currently only 170 temples in operation throughout the world. In them are performed the highest sacraments of the faith, and only worthy members are admitted.
